carload.desc: An LCL shipment from Bittner, Hunsicker & Co. (misspelled quite badly on the bill) of Allentown. This shipment is marked with a commodity no. of 2980; no listing of PRR freight commodity numbers is known. Unfortunately, the freight agent neglected to mark the car this shipment traveled in!

Crammed into a boxcar for its journey from Ohio, this "gasoline locomotive" was a small narrow-gauge 4-wheel industrial locomotive built by the Plymouth Locomotive Works (Fate-Root-Heath), a 7-ton Model DLB, for hauling mine cars around the clay pits. A photo of it in operation can be seen here, courtesy of Penn State University Library's Special Collections.

carload.freight: 3 Cartons Catsup in Glass, 1 Box General Goods, 1 Pail Candy, 1 Box Wash Tablets, 10 Cartons Milk, 3 Bags Sugar, 1 Case Sugar, 1 Case Sugar, 1 Carton Powdered Sugar
carload.desc: An order of foodstuffs from a grocer in Philadelphia.

carload.freight: 1 Carton Strike-Anywhere Matches, 1 Carton Sugar, 4 Cases Cakes
carload.desc: "Yellow Label" is noted below the carton of matches on the bill, referring to the system of hazardous cargo labels commonly in use at this time. Yellow labels were used for freight that was inflammable, but not liable to explode. CITE THIS WITH SOMETHING!

A correction issued to a previous freight bill for the described shipment, correcting the destination listed as "Williamsburg - Oreminea - PA", i.e. the branch and siding for the Woodbury Clay Co. Evidently it had not been deliverable as originally specified.

carload.shipper: Dean Coal Co. Fruhlinger Colliery No. 1
carload.desc: This bill has been the principal source of aggravation in this project. A reward is offered to any individual who can conclusively determine what coal mine this refers to and where it was located.

carload.shipper: Dean Coal Co. Fruhlinger Colliery No. 1
carload.desc: Both freight bills from the Dean Coal Co. give the same station number (9593), and so this also refers to the "Fruhlinger Coll. No. 1" from the previous bill.

carload.freight: 1 Box Rwy. Car Drawbar Springs, 6 Rwy. Car Drawbars
carload.desc: The freight car parts in question are repair parts for the small narrow-gauge dump cars used within the mine. Of note on this bill is the "Stop this car at" field at the upper left. This LCL shipment arrived at Altoona in a CB&Q car, and was transloaded into a PRR car for final delivery. CB&Q #42247 was a class XF-8 50' furniture car, wood-framed, built 1899—a very large car when built, but by 1933, an old and decrepit one. See Rail Model Journal, July 1989, p. 47 for more information on these cars.

carload.shipper: Penna. Coal & Coke Co. Penna. Coll. No. 10

carload.desc: A shipment of mattresses and bedding for the residents of Oreminea.

carload.freight: 1 Case Blasting Caps, 1 Case Safety Fuses
carload.desc: This form is a receipt for a Bill of Lading, as opposed to a Freight Bill: i.e., a receipt of the shipment itself and not an invoice for the payment thereof. Unfortunately, the car in which these supplies were shipped is not specified on the bill, but one thing is for certain—it would have been placarded "EXPLOSIVES"! These were supplies for blasting within the mine pit at Oreminea.

An LCL shipment of lead-acid storage batteries, which would have required "DANGEROUS" placards on the outside of the car. At the time, railroad shipping regulations utilized colored labels for individual packages of hazardous cargo, with a white label corresponding to acids/corrosive liquids. This shipment was ordered from the Butler Bros. supply company but did not originate at their plant, instead being shipped from a supplier somewhere in Brooklyn and departing the city by carfloat. The exact meaning of "501 Bdks Bklyn Ba Wav Tfr N.J." is unclear but most likely refers to the shipment being received and forwarded via the freight transfer terminal in nearby Waverly, N.J., which ceased operations shortly after WWII.

carload.freight: 1 Carton Liquid Drugs, 2 Bundles Tires, 1 Carton Sewing Notions, 1 Carton Sanitary Napkins, 1 Bundle Grass Edgers, 1 Bundle Garden Hose
carload.desc: An LCL shipment of various supplies for the general store in Oreminea.
A small LCL package, shipped out of Baltimore's President Street freight station.

A mobile pump on wheels, probably for draining water out of the clay pits. Stapled to the bill is a a neat little snapshot of daily life around the Woodbury Clay Co., a handwritten note concerning "office expenses".

carload.freight: 2 Boxes Bolts, 6 Steel Bars, 1 Carton Washers

carload.desc: A single oil dipstick for a gas mining shovel, shipped from Lorain, OH on the Nickel Plate Road through to Erie, PA, then down into Pittsburgh on the PRR, where it was transloaded into this car from a car not specified on the bill at the 11th St. Freight Station before finally traveling to Oreminea.

Evidently the mining shovel in question needed more than the dipstick from the previous bill. This shipment left Lorain in NKP #85571, a double-sheathed 40' boxcar inherited by the NKP in 1922 from the Lake Erie & Western RR. It too was transloaded into a PRR car at 11th St. Station in Pittsburgh for final delivery.

carload.freight: 1 Keg of Chain, 1 Carton Wool Waste
carload.desc: Wool waste would have been soaked in oil and used for packing journal bearings on mine cars and other equipment with plain bearings.

carload.shipper: American Fork & Hoe Co. Skelton Shovel Works
carload.freight: 2 Bundles Long Handle Shovels (1 dozen each)
carload.desc: Transloaded at Altoona from PRR #43668, an X23 boxcar.

carload.freight: One Lorain Type 40 Power Gas Shovel
carload.desc:
The only non-PRR document in this collection, a B&O freight bill for the shipment of a new power mining shovel to the Woodbury Clay Co. It shipped out of Lorain on the B&O, through Akron, OH to the lorem ipsum dolor sit amet. The bill specifies the weight of the load as 34300 lbs, "exact blocking wt. 800 lbs.;" this phrasing indicates the weight of the wooden chocks, supports, and chains used to secure the power shovel to the car. While a "40 ft car" was ordered, a 50' PRR F30 was supplied.

This Model 40 gas-powered mining shovel was not the first to be operated in the mines of the Woodbury Clay Co. The era of steam shovels was already over in Oreminea; this shovel appears to have supplemented an earlier gas-powered model that was in need of repair. A photo appears in that penn state gallery, link to it, finish description, lorem ipsum dolor sit amet.

carload.freight: 1 keg RR spikes, 1 keg RR bolts, 1 iron jack w/ handle att.

carload.desc: Shipped Railway Express on NKP, transloaded from DL&W #40267 at Cleveland, routed via Ashtabula. Check this.
A mobile pump on wheels, probably for draining water out of the clay pits. Transloaded into this car at Pittsburgh. Check this.
"Paid from Cash Sales". Shipped from Trenton, NJ freight station by an unknown party.
NYC&StL, via PRR from Ashtabula OH. Consigned to Woodbury Clay Co. but delivered to Ganister, PA, just up the valley and one stop beyond Williamsburg. No idea why they had it sent there.
Received from consignor at Jay St. LCL Terminal, Brooklyn, NY.
Stapled to this bill are three additional Railway Express receipts for individual boxes of shoes that arrived at Oreminea on recent dates. Each is listed as a separate shipment.
Railway Express receipt only, no car or routing information.
Railway Express receipt only, no car or routing information.
Railway Express receipt only, no car or routing information.
Routed via Fulton Jct. in Baltimore, there transferred and delivered on the Western Maryland.

carload.consignee: Bethlehem Steel Co. Sparrows Point Plant

carload.desc: Routed via Johnsonburg, PA and the BR&P (Buffalo, Rochester & Pittsburgh)
Routed via Fulton Jct. in Baltimore, there transferred and delivered on the Western Maryland.

A single car of coal from a Dean Coal Co. mine in Coalport to the Woodbury Clay Co. This is the only C.T.1098 "Report of Carloads Weighed" form in the collection that actually represents an inbound shipment to Oreminea.

carload.consignee: Carnegie-Illinois Steel Co. Mingo Works (Carnegie Steel)
carload.desc: A weight receipt from the East Altoona Scales, prepared by a Weighmaster there who evidently was not armed with a typewriter. Notably, the date here is incorporated into the scale agent's rubber stamp.
This car would have traveled all but the the final mile of its journey on PRR rails, with the final switching from the nearby PRR receiving yard into the mill performed by the South Buffalo Railway.
This car would have traveled all but the the final mile of its journey on PRR rails, with the final switching from the nearby PRR receiving yard into the mill performed by the South Buffalo Railway.

A shipment to Canada! This car was sent all the way up the PRR Buffalo Line through to Buffalo, NY, then transferred to the MCRR (Michigan Central) and ultimately the TH&B (Toronto, Hamilton & Buffalo).

This shipment, <a href="glossary.html">reconsigned<\a> before departure the previous day, was routed via the PRR's South Side junction (where the Mon Line branches off the main), through to the Panhandle down to Wheeling, WV, where it was finally interchanged to and delivered by the B&O.
A very spooky shipment.

Another shipment from the East Altoona scales, where in the absence of a typewriter, Weighmaster G. P. Towsey got to show off his impressive penmanship. Later bills for shipments to this plant specify a routing via Hobart, IL, and there transferred to the EJ&E. (Elgin, Joliet & Eastern) for delivery.
Routed via Fulton Jct. in Baltimore, there transferred and delivered on the Western Maryland.

Oddly, as evidenced by two separate bills, two separate outbound cars from the Woodbury Clay Co. turned up to be weighed and forwarded at Altoona on the same day. One of them must have been held up in the yard. (Multiple cars traveling together are listed on a single bill)

Oddly, as evidenced by two separate bills, two separate outbound cars from the Woodbury Clay Co. turned up to be weighed and forwarded at Altoona on the same day. One of them must have been held up in the yard. (Multiple cars traveling together are listed on a single bill)
The Pennsy's finest equipment showed up for this shipment: a pair of brand new, nearly sequential X29 boxcars out on one of their first journeys after delivery.

carload.consignee: Youngstown Sheet & Tube Co. Campbell Works Converting Mills
Bethlehem Steel Co. Sparrows Point Plant

carload.desc: Routed via Fulton Jct. in Baltimore, there transferred and delivered on the Western Maryland.
This carload was sent down the Southwest Penna. branch to Everson (adjacent to Scottdale, 1945-p. 242), and there was transferred to the B&O for its journey down into West Virginia.
Delivered via the Indiana Harbor Belt from PRR interchange in East Chicago.
There must have been a momentary shortage of empty boxcars in the Altoona yard that day, as this is the only hopper sent to Oreminea for clay loading

carload.consignee: Youngstown Sheet & Tube Co. Campbell Works Converting Mills

carload.desc: An unusual shipment, pre-purchased and shipped by the A. M. Byers Co. from the Woodbury Clay Co. to its plant along the Ohio River. Equally unusual is that they ordered a gondola, instead of a boxcar, for loading.

Routed via Potomac Yard, there interchanged to the Southern Rwy. Interchanged at Ensley, AL and delivered by Birmingham Southern RR. Potomac Yard was the major railyard connecting the North to the South in Washington D.C., where the PRR interchanged with the SOU via the RF&P, which operated the yard. It was ripped up in 1989 by the RF&P's successor, CSX, in an attempt to sell the land it occupied.

carload.consignee: Carnegie-Illinois Steel Co. Mingo Works (Carnegie Steel)
Carnegie-Illinois Steel Co. South Works (Illinois Steel)

carload.desc: Describe what all these prepaid bills and receipts are doing here.
Routed via Fulton Jct. in Baltimore, there transferred and delivered on the Western Maryland.

This carload of clay was not traveling to a refractory manufacturer--its destination was a chemical testing laboratory for the clay industry. One wonders what possible purpose they could have had for an entire car of clay.

carload.consignee: Bethlehem Steel Co. Sparrows Point Plant
Carnegie-Illinois Steel Co. Mingo Works (Carnegie Steel)
Youngstown Sheet & Tube Co. Campbell Works Converting Mills
Bethlehem Steel Co. Sparrows Point Plant
Carnegie-Illinois Steel Co. Edgar Thompson Works (Carnegie Steel)
Carnegie-Illinois Steel Co. Mingo Works (Carnegie Steel)

carload.desc: Interchanged to the NYC&St.L (New York, Chicago & St. Louis RR, aka the Nickel Plate Road) at Cleveland, through to destination.
This carload was sent down the Southwest Penna. branch to Everson (adjacent to Scottdale, 1945-p. 242), and there was transferred to the B&O for its journey down into West Virginia.

It seems likely that this bill is incorrect, and was actually a shipment from Thomas Sant & Sons. There are two separate bills from this date, each for two cars. While both listed as being shipped by the Woodbury Clay Co., two separate shipments on the same day is unusual, and all other shipments to either McFeely or Locke Insulator have been from Sant so far.

carload.consignee: Carnegie-Illinois Steel Co. Mingo Works (Carnegie Steel)

carload.desc: Shipped up the PRR through Williamsport, Elmira, and on up the Elmira Branch to Canandaigua, NY, there interchanged to NYC for the last nine miles of its journey.
enter description here
enter description here

carload.consignee: Carnegie-Illinois Steel Co. Edgar Thompson Works (Carnegie Steel)

carload.desc: An export load to Canada. Describe why on the Forms page.

Unique among the collection, this is a freight bill for a diverted carload—a shipment that made it as far as Altoona before being cancelled and sent back to Oreminea. The bill provides an advance (credit) to the Woodbury Clay Co.'s account, to offset the initial charge from when the car was shipped out. This car was originally bound for the Taylor, Smith & Taylor Co. in Chester, WV. Unfortunately, its original waybill did not survive alongside this one.
